title: For Fellowkids Studio Kiln Shows How Brands Can Behave Like Fans
source_credit: Work by For Fellowkids via The Brand Identity
summary: Studio Kiln developed a dynamic brand identity for Fellowkids, an agency deeply embedded in esports and entertainment culture. The core strategic insight: design a brand that authentically *is* a fan. This manifested as the versatile "Fellowkid" character, initially conceived as a collectible 3D art toy, embodying genuine immersion. A vibrant Y2K-inspired visual system and bespoke typography complete the aesthetic, positioning Fellowkids with cultural resonance and adaptability, mirroring their mission to build fervent communities.
fullContent:
Fellowkids: Crafting Fandom from the Inside Out

Fellowkids, an agency adept at cultivating fervent fandoms for its clients, found itself in a paradoxical position: its own brand had become a relic, no longer reflecting its burgeoning success, sophisticated work, or inherent "rock and roll" spirit. They required an identity transcending corporate representation, capable of commanding attention in high-stakes pitches, anchoring presentations, and authentically embodying their seriously playful, confidently edgy, and anti-corporate ethos. Studio Kiln’s response was rooted in a deceptively simple yet profound insight: if Fellowkids excelled at *building* fandom, its own brand must *behave* like a fan. This mandated an identity eschewing corporate posturing, opting instead for responsiveness, playfulness, and the dynamic adaptability of a community insider.

This core philosophy materialized as the "Fellowkid" character, a hooded figure designed as the emotional anchor of the brand. The choice was deliberate, recognizing the hoodie as a universal signifier across fan subcultures—a symbol of belonging and anonymity. Crucially, the Fellowkid’s silhouette was engineered for infinite adaptability, effortlessly swapping colors, textures, and graphics to represent diverse teams, titles, and moments. Rather than a mere two-dimensional icon, the concept was revolutionary: the Fellowkid was initially modelled as a physical vinyl art toy. This tangible manifestation wasn’t an afterthought but the conceptual cornerstone, transforming the brand itself into a coveted piece of collectible culture, something fans could genuinely own.

Around this central character, Studio Kiln constructed a vibrant Y2K-inspired visual universe, drawing from nostalgic tech aesthetics. Translucent plastics, candy-bright hues, saturated neons, and deep blacks form a dynamic palette, strategically deploying hot accents for high-energy moments and softer hardware greys to ground the system. This purposeful dynamism allows the brand to be both bold and refined. Typography is anchored by Aeonik, lending a clear, neutral, credible voice, with Aeonik Mono subtly infusing technical flair for labels and UI elements. This pairing harmonizes with bespoke, Y2K-flavored lettering elsewhere, ensuring balance. The entire modular system functions as a dynamic "digital sticker sheet" – an eclectic kit of icons, type, and decals, framed by a simple grid, facilitating effortless, plug-and-play asset creation and lively engagement.

This meticulously crafted identity proved immediately and profoundly transformative. Fellowkids reported tangible successes, notably securing a significant pitch where the client explicitly praised the brand’s fresh, exciting, and clean presentation. The vinyl Fellowkid toy, in particular, has garnered immense enthusiasm, hailed as "playful but premium, collectible but accessible"—a perfect embodiment of the agency’s commitment to taking fandom seriously without taking themselves too seriously. Beyond commercial wins, the rebrand has unleashed Fellowkids’ authentic voice, aligning their visual presence with their elevated work and unapologetic edge. It has evolved the brand from something observed into something deeply felt and rooted for, rekindling a potent sense of nostalgia, collection, and belonging.

title: How Kimera Built Cursors Identity Around A Custom Typeface System
source_credit: Work by How Kimera via The Brand Identity
summary: Kimera led a strategic brand refresh for Cursor, crafting a sophisticated identity for the professional AI code editor. The core deliverable was Cursor Gothic, a bespoke typographic system engineered for seamless integration across both brand communication and product interface. This high-performance visual language, featuring refined logotypes and screen-optimized icons, balances technical precision with a human touch, ensuring a cohesive and distinctive user experience for developers.
fullContent:
When the team behind Cursor, a sophisticated code editor, sought to evolve their brand, their brief was clear: refine, don't reinvent. The challenge for Kimera, the type foundry tasked with the project, was to elevate an existing identity – specifically Ben Barry’s original logo – ensuring it became more versatile and impeccably optimised for diverse digital environments. The brand tone needed to navigate a subtle duality, marrying high-end technical sophistication with an accessible, human warmth. A crucial element of this transformation was the development of a bespoke typeface, which would not only anchor the brand's visual language but also seamlessly transition into a monospace version for Cursor’s core product: the code editor itself. This demanded a design strategy that respected existing brand equity while innovating for ultimate functional integration.

At the heart of Kimera’s creative solution lies Cursor Gothic, a bespoke typeface expertly crafted from their esteemed retail offering, Waldenburg. Cursor’s admiration for Waldenburg’s blend of Akzidenz-Grotesk’s rationalism and Univers’ analogue warmth guided the adaptation. Cursor Gothic was subtly condensed, its squarish forms and higher contrast refined to ensure a smoother rhythm across extensive text and at smaller sizes. A truly innovative feature emerged in the form of "logo ligatures," collapsing the traditional boundary between branding and typography. By embedding the refined Cursor logos directly into the font, designers can now achieve perfect optical alignment with accompanying text, eliminating common integration headaches. This sophisticated logo system further evolved Ben Barry's original cube design into three optically balanced versions – a crisp 2D for primary use, a graphic 2.5D, and a fully rendered 3D iteration for app icons – each meticulously adjusted to defy geometric purity for optimal screen perception.

Beyond foundational typography, the identity expanded into a holistic ecosystem. A custom icon set, harmonizing with the typeface's aesthetic, was meticulously engineered with rounded caps and squarish forms for clarity and consistency across both website UI and the dynamic code editor. The chosen colour palette intentionally diverges from conventional tech norms, featuring warm undertones and an orange accent inspired by power tools – a subtle yet potent reinforcement of Cursor’s human-centric positioning. This comprehensive approach culminates in an engaging website that transcends typical showcases, integrating live, interactive product elements built directly in CSS. Users can explore key functionalities, bridging brand narrative and actual product interaction. This meticulously curated identity, rooted in refining existing equity, establishes a robust and evolving foundation. With the forthcoming Cursor Mono, a monospace extension designed for the code editor, the project achieves a rare synergy: a unified typographic language spanning every touchpoint from marketing to the intimate environment of development itself, ultimately enhancing Cursor’s industry leadership through unparalleled brand-product cohesion.

title: How Wedge Shifted Allergen Brand Growhappy From Fear To Confidence
source_credit: Work by How Wedge via The Brand Identity
summary: This branding project for GrowHappy aimed to redefine early allergen introduction, transforming parental apprehension into informed confidence. We strategically pioneered the "ImmunoNutrition" category, reframing early exposure as a vital immune-building step, distinct from traditional fear-driven messaging. The visual identity, inspired by comforting storybooks, features a soft, reassuring palette and inviting typography. This cohesive system successfully repositioned GrowHappy, empowering parents and establishing a new standard for preventive infant health.
fullContent:
The genesis of GrowHappy, rooted in founder Stephanie Wibom's personal experience with her daughter's severe allergies, illuminated a critical void: bridging scientific evidence on early allergen introduction with practical parental action. Despite growing consensus, the existing landscape was dominated by fear-based messaging and clinical aesthetics, fostering anxiety rather than empowerment. Independent creative studio Wedge faced the profound challenge of transcending this apprehension, crafting a brand that not only communicated vital science but genuinely shifted parental mindsets from fear of feeding allergens to confidence in prevention.

Wedge’s strategic breakthrough arrived through the power of language. They coined the innovative category of "ImmunoNutrition," ingeniously reframing early allergen exposure from a potential threat to a foundational act of building a robust immune system. This semantic alchemy, paired with the intuitively named "ImmunoButters" product line, immediately clarified both format and profound benefits. This linguistic masterstroke created crucial distance from competitors, simultaneously positioning GrowHappy as the definitive leader in an empowering new category, championing "food freedom" for families grounded in scientific expertise.

The visual lexicon developed by Wedge deliberately diverged from the clinical, drawing instead from the comforting familiarity of premium baby products and classic storybooks. This psychological pivot aimed to offer reassurance, not medical anxiety. The palette features soft, muted tones—a serene departure from sterile whites or bold primaries. Typography skillfully balances clarity with warmth, conveying authority without intimidation. A distinguishing element is the custom illustration style, inspired by vintage botanical plates. These detailed yet delicate depictions of fruits and vegetables signal whole foods, imbuing packaging with heritage, trustworthiness, and subtle educational elegance. Every element was crafted to foster confidence and calm.

The culmination of this thoughtful design strategy is a brand that acts as both expert guide and empathetic companion. GrowHappy’s soft, organized, and profoundly reassuring touchpoints instantly communicate product function and importance, cultivating parental confidence through clarity. The packaging elegantly recontextualizes allergens not as risks, but as essential components of a wholesome diet fundamental to immune and gut health. Launched during Mother’s Day and Allergy Awareness Week, GrowHappy stands as the pioneering brand within the ImmunoNutrition category, having successfully forged a new narrative where early allergen introduction is an empowering journey of nourishment and courage.

title: Los Yorks Pixel Based System Gives Netflixs Eyeline A Bold New Vision
source_credit: Work by Los Yorks via The Brand Identity
summary: Los York engineered a distinctive visual identity for Eyeline, Netflix’s VFX powerhouse. The core concept leverages the pixel as a foundational building block, enabling a scalable, modular design system. A dynamic color architecture differentiates its integrated divisions (VFX, Studios, Labs) within an RGB spectrum. Typographic juxtaposition of classic serif and modern sans articulates cinematic heritage with technological precision, crafting a sophisticated brand language that transcends industry tropes.
fullContent:
Eyeline, a titan in the realm of visual innovation spanning VFX, virtual production, and experimental technologies, faced the intricate challenge of unifying its three distinct divisions – VFX, Studios, and Labs – under a single, cohesive brand identity. Their existing presence needed to transcend common industry clichés, articulating a sophisticated balance between cutting-edge technology and profound creative artistry, while also scaling globally for partners like Netflix. The task for design studio Los York was to craft a system that felt both bespoke and boundless, rooted in legacy yet poised for the future, ultimately framing Eyeline's world-class craft with refined confidence.

Los York’s ingenious solution stemmed from a deceptively simple yet profoundly powerful concept: the pixel as origin. This foundational idea – the smallest unit of vision, a single spark that unlocks infinite visual potential – became the perfect metaphor for Eyeline’s work, where technology and creativity are inextricably linked. From this core, a modular, expressive design language was meticulously constructed, offering a shared graphic DNA built on structure, precision, and limitless possibility. Each division gained a distinct voice through color, with Studios adopting red, VFX green, and Labs blue, together forming a complete RGB spectrum – a subtle yet potent nod to the elemental forces behind all image-making.

This pixel concept evolved into a dynamic, grid-based system, designed to expand from micro-detail to macro-expression, mirroring Eyeline's collaborative workflow and fluid movement across film sets, digital pipelines, and R&D environments. The system, built on clarity and control, allows layouts to shift and reconfigure seamlessly while maintaining an underlying order. Complementing this, the typography pairs the cinematic warmth of ITC Garamond Light Narrow with the technical precision of Netflix Sans. This deliberate tension between serif and sans-serif elegantly reflects the brand's inherent duality: imagination meeting engineering, human legacy converging with digital frontiers, creating a distinct typographic voice tuned for impact and nuance.

The resulting identity strategically steps away from the flashy visual effects often seen in the industry. Instead, Los York opted for an approach where the brand acts as a clean, confident window and canvas, allowing Eyeline's groundbreaking work to take center stage. The new brand has been met with significant acclaim, with Eyeline’s CEO Jeffrey Shapiro praising its ability to capture "the spirit of who we are and where we are headed." Ultimately, Los York succeeded in delivering an identity that transcends mere aesthetics, marking a true shift for Eyeline: from a name rooted in technology to a powerful creative force defined by an unyielding spirit of imagination and possibility.
